attributes.title: A cognitive and categorical approach to the perceived performance of hybrid organizations

q1.value: A cognitive and categorical approach to the perceived performance of hybrid organizations

q4.value:
- For an hybrid organisations that accentuates its commercial goal,  a piecemeal-based priming based on organisational goals (relative to a category priming) increases its perceived performance evaluation
- This effect is due to a reduction in the multi category discount 

- For an hybrid organisations that attenuates its commercial goal,  a category priming (vs. a piecemeal-based priming based on organisational goals) increases its perceived performance evaluation
- This effect is due to a reduction in the multi category discount

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: 2x2 design manipulating piecemeal and category cognition

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: data collected on M turk, participants will be financially rewarded.

To manipulate category and piecemeal cognition, we will rely on mindset priming (Bargh and Chartrand, 2000; Kopetz and Kruglanski, 2008). Mindset priming is appropriate for our study because it pushes participants to evaluate an entity with an established cognitive framework in mind: either based on a fit with a category (categorical cognition) or a focus on the different functions and goals of an object (piecemeal cognition). In the categorical cognition, participants will be  asked to categorize 10 objects into 3 prototypical categories. In contrast, in the piecemeal cognition, participants will be asked to select one of the 10 objects described in the categorical cognition condition and use 5 words to depict its specific features and functions (Kopetz and Kruglanski, 2008).

All items are on a 10-point scale. 
2 items for perceived performance: "Do you think Clean and Co. will remain in operation in the future?
.?"/ "Do you think clean and Co. is likely to survive in the long run .?"

Third item: "Would you hire Clean and Co."?


categorization questions:
- how would you categorize Clean and Co. with 4 answers 1.A for-profit, 2.A nonprofit, 3.an hybrid 4. I don't know
- Do you think 'Clean and Co.' can be considered as a social enterprise? (10 point scale) 

Mediators:
3 items: 
1.How easy is it to understand what Clean and Co. is doing? 
2.How clear is Clean and Co. identity? 
3.Do you have doubts about Clean and Co.’s competence?

Attention check 

controls:
How many years of business experience do you have?
CSR knowledge
gender 
age
ANOVAS, comparison of means, mediation analyses

attributes.title: Facial Anomalies and Visual Attention (FAVA)
attributes.description: Recent evidence suggests people experience biases against those with facial anomalies. Although biasing effects have been reported in the literature for both explicit and implicit attitudes, implicit biases have been shown to be particularly robust. The effects of such biases on behavior, however, are poorly understood. It is unknown, for instance, whether implicit bias modulates visual attention paid to facial anomalies and, if observed, whether such effects are attenuated following surgical correction. Furthermore, psychological dispositions like empathy and disgust sensitivity have been hypothesized to shape bias, although additional empirical work is necessary to test these hypotheses.

q1.value: Visual attention paid to faces before versus after treatment to correct anomalies

q2.value: Giap Vu, Clifford Workman, Laura S. Humphries, Anjan Chatterjee, Jesse A. Taylor

q3.value: Recent evidence suggests people experience biases against those with facial anomalies (Jamrozik et al., 2019; Hartung et al., 2019). Although biasing effects have been reported in the literature for both explicit and implicit attitudes, implicit biases have been shown to be particularly robust. The effects of such biases on behavior, however, are poorly understood. It is unknown, for instance, whether implicit bias modulates visual attention paid to facial anomalies and, if observed, whether such effects are attenuated following surgical correction. Furthermore, psychological dispositions like empathy and disgust sensitivity have been hypothesized to shape bias, although additional empirical work is necessary to test these hypotheses.

q4.value: We hypothesize that visual attention will differ between faces with visible anomalies and faces in which such anomalies have been surgically corrected. Specifically, we predict that visual attention will be directed *away* from the affected side before compared to after correction. Replicating our previous work, we predict that people will demonstrate robust implicit biases against people with facial anomalies. Importantly, we further predict that those people who look away most often will demonstrate the strongest implicit biases, and that this relationship will be mediated by trait disgust sensitivity. Alternatively, visual attention may instead be directed *towards* the affected side before compared to after correction, with greater visual attention correlating positively with implicit bias, with this effect mediated negatively by trait empathy.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
People interested in participating will be contacted to arrange an initial in-person study visit, and will be provided with a link to an on line survey, for which they must provide consent, and which includes questions about their demographics and measures to assess relevant psychological dispositions: the Procedural and Distributive Just World Beliefs Scale (PaDJWBS), Social Dominance Orientation Scale (SDO), Interpersonal Reactivity Index (IRI), and Three-Domain Disgust Scale (3DD).

At the in-person study visit, participants will first complete written informed consent. Participants will then complete two runs of an eye-tracking task with calibration performed before both runs. In each run, participants will see front-facing images of faces either before or after surgical treatment to correct hemifacial microsomia. Hemifacial microsomia is a developmental disorder that, without treatment, renders faces asymmetrical. Participants will see face images belonging to 17 different people before and after corrective treatment (N = 34 images). These images were then duplicated and mirrored, minimizing effects of left gaze bias and improving statistical power, resulting in a total of N = 68 images per run (Alpers, 2008; Alpers & Gerdes, 2007; Meyer-Marcotty, Gerdes, Reuther, Stellzig-Eisenhauer, & Alpers, 2010; Meyer-Marcotty, Gerdes, Stellzig-Eisenhauer, & Alpers, 2011; Quast et al., 2018). Each image is shown to participants for 5 seconds in a pseudo-randomized fashion (both regarding order of appearance and the side of the screen on which it appears; Meyer-Marcotty et al., 2011; Warne, Hallac, Kane, Derderian, & Seaward, 2019). Images will be separated by periods of fixation lasting 1.5 seconds. Each run takes around 10 minutes to complete. Four areas of interest (AOIs) have been defined on each face: cheek and ear (CE), forehead and orbit (FO), mandible and chin (MC), and nose and lips (NL). For each AOI, we will calculate numbers of and durations of fixations for each image.

Next, participants will complete the Implicit Association Test (IAT), where they will associate good and bad words with people before and after surgery to correct a facial anomaly. Then, as in Jamrozik et al. (2019), participants will rate the faces on attractiveness, trustworthiness, contentedness, dominance, anxiousness, and their own responses (valence, arousal, dominance). Finally, participants will complete an explicit bias questionnaire. Participants will be compensated for their time and participation in the study.

q9.value: Given the fully within-subjects design of the study, all participants will complete all conditions rendering randomization inapplicable.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Healthy adult volunteers (aged 18 and older) will be recruited from the Philadelphia metropolitan area, including but not necessarily limited to University students, to participate. In order to participate, participants must be aged 18 or older and cannot have significant visual impairments that would disrupt their ability to complete the study procedures. After completing the study, participants will be compensated for their time.

q14.value: A power analysis, computed with 1,000 Monte Carlo simulations using data reported in Linz et al. (2016), suggest a sample of N = 60 participants will provide sufficient power to detect the effects of interest (1-β > 0.8). A secondary power analysis, using the same procedure but informed by pilot data acquired in 5 volunteers, also indicated N = 60 participants will provide adequate statistical power.

question.value:
* Eye-tracking (numbers of and durations of fixations in 4 areas of interest: cheek and ear, forehead and orbit, mandible and chin, and nose and lips)
* Face ratings (attractiveness, trustworthiness, contentedness, dominance, anxiousness, personal reactions [valence, arousal, dominance])
* Implicit biases (Implicit Association Test [IAT])
* Explicit biases (Explicit Bias Questionnaire [EBQ])
* Dispositional measures (trait empathy, Interpersonal Reactivity Index; justice beliefs, Procedural and Distributive Just World Beliefs Scale; egalitarianism, Social Dominance Orientation Scale; sensitivity to disgust, Three-Domain Disgust Scale)
* Demographic variables (age, sex, gender, sexual orientation, education, income, political views)

Linear mixed effect models will identify within-subject differences in visual attention (i.e., number of fixations, duration of fixations) depending on a face type (Pre-Treatment | Post-Treatment) by affected side interaction (Left | Right; note that by using mirrored images, our unilateral areas of interest capture visual attention to both the affected and non-affected sides of the face). Random slopes and intercepts will be modeled unless the inclusion of random slopes prevents model convergence. This model will test for an interaction between face type and affected side on visual attention. For comparison, an additional null model will be computed and its Akaike information criterion (AIC) compared, which estimates out-of-sample prediction error. The model with the superior AIC will be selected. This procedure will be repeated with implicit bias scores included to examine whether implicit bias explains a significant proportion of the variance.

q20.value: The Implicit Association Test (IAT) is comprised of seven parts. In the first part, participants press keys on a keyboard in order to categorize images of faces as anomalous or typical. Second, using the same keys, participants categorize words as good (i.e., happy) or bad (i.e., sickening). Third, participants again use the same keys to categorize both faces and words (e.g., anomalous faces and good words, typical faces and bad words). The fourth part replicates the third. In parts 5 through 7, the mapping between faces and keys is swapped (e.g., such that anomalous faces are paired with bad words, and typical faces are paired with good words). The average reaction time when associating anomalous faces with bad words (and typical faces with good words; e.g., part 7) is then subtracted from the average reaction time when associating anomalous faces with good words (and typical faces with bad words; e.g. part 4). This difference score is then taken over the standard deviation of these reaction times in order to calculate the IAT d' score (Greenwald et al., 2003). If participants are faster at associating anomalous faces with bad words than good, this would be reflected in a positive d' score and indicative of implicit bias. If implicit bias is not present, however, then the IAT d' score should be negative.

q21.value:
Significance will be determined with an alpha = 0.05, with Benjamini-Hochberg correction to
control the false discovery rate.

q22.value: We will use an attention check to ensure participants are engaged with the online survey. Participants will be informed that, if they respond to the attention check incorrectly, they will be excluded from the study and may not receive full payment. Implicit bias scores will be calculated according to standard criteria and may be excluded in the event their scores are driven by confounds.

q23.value: The survey is designed such that all responses are required and participants cannot advance without responding to each question. Participants whose IAT or EBQ data are missing, either through testing error or exclusion, will be excluded from analyses in which these variables are included.

q24.value: Secondary exploratory analyses will examine whether relations between visual attention and implicit bias are mediated by purportedly relevant psychological dispositions (e.g. trait affective and cognitive empathy, sensitivity to disgust).

attributes.title: Social Class, Political Orientation and Lay Beliefs
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

dataCollectionDates.value:
Estimated start date of data collection: January 2020
Estimated end date of data collection: February 2020

question2a.value: It is a correlational study. All variables are between-participants. The primary independent variable is SSC-Com. The mediators are PRD and SDO.

question2b.value: The dependent variables are lay beliefs about intelligence and social class (Dweck, 2000) and essentialist beliefs about social class (Kraus & Keltner, 2013).

question3b.value: The primary moderator is political orientation.

question10b.value: After providing consent, participants will first answer questions about their subjective social class (Adler, Epel, Castellazzo & Ickovics, 2000). Participants will then answer questions about their lay beliefs about intelligence and social class (Dweck, 2000; 6-items each; 1=Strongly disagree, 6=Strongly agree), and the 10-item measure of essentialist beliefs about social class (Kraus and Keltner, 2013; 1=Strongly disagree, 6=Strongly agree). Participants will complete the 16-item measure of social dominance orientation (SDO7; Ho et al., 2015; 1=Strongly oppose, 7=Strongly favor) and the 5-item measure of personal relative deprivation (Callen, 2008; 1=Strongly disagree, 6=Strongly agree). Participants will also complete questions about their self-income, parental income, self-education, parental education, and a 1-item measure of their political orientation (1=Very liberal, 7=Very Conservative). In addition, we will be measuring general demographic variables (e.g., race, gender). Finally, participants will be debriefed and receive a code which they will have to enter into Mturk to receive compensation for their participation in the study.

question4b.value: Based on the power analysis, the largest number of participants needed to detect the smallest hypothesized effect is 1350 participants. Expecting about 10% dropout or unusable data, we will be collecting data from 1500 participants.

question5b.value: Participants will be collected via the online platform Amazon Mechanical Turk.

question6b.value: The sample size was based on a power analysis using the relevant path estimates from an earlier exploratory study. The lavaan package (Rosseel, 2012) was used to model the pathways in the path analysis. The simsem package (Jorgensen, Pornprasertmanit, Miller & Schoemann, 2018) was used to run simulation models to find the sample size needed for .80 power at .05 alpha (see attached file).

question7b.value: We will stop collecting data once we reach our target sample size.

question8b.value:
1. Participants who do not answer the attention checks correctly will be excluded from analysis.   
2. Participants will see each variable of interest (SSC-Com, SDO, PRD, Lay Beliefs about Intelligence, Lay Beliefs about Social Class, Essentialist Beliefs of Social Class, and Political Orientation) on a separate page. For these variables, we will have a timer on each page. This timer will be hidden to the participants and only available to the researchers for analysis purposes. Participants who complete the page in less time than the number of items on the page multiplied by 1.5 seconds will be excluded from analysis. 
3. Participants who have the same IP address will be excluded from analysis. 
4. Participants who are not located in the United States will be excluded from analysis.

question7c.value: For the path analysis, listwise deletion will be used.

question1a.value:
Hypothesis 1: Higher levels of Subjective Social Class relative to the Community (SSC-Com) will predict lay beliefs about (a) intelligence and (b) social class as less malleable, and (c) more essentialist beliefs about social class. 

Hypothesis 2: Higher levels of SSC-Com will predict lower levels of Personal Relative Deprivation (PRD). 

Hypothesis 3: Higher levels of PRD will predict lay beliefs about (a) intelligence and (b) social class as less malleable, and (c) more essentialist beliefs about social class.   

Hypothesis 4: Higher levels of SSC-Com will predict higher levels of Social Dominance Orientation (SDO). 

Hypothesis 5: Higher levels of SDO will predict lay beliefs about (a) intelligence and (b) social class as less malleable, and (c) more essentialist beliefs about social class.   

Hypothesis 6: The predictive effects of SSC-Com on beliefs (Hypothesis 1) will be mediated by (a) PRD (Hypotheses 2-3) and (b) SDO (Hypotheses 4-5).

question2a.value:
Hypothesis 1*: The effects described in Hypothesis 1 will be significant for conservatives but not for liberals. 

Hypothesis 2*: The effects described in Hypothesis 2 will be significant for liberals but not for conservatives.
  
Hypothesis 4*: The effects described in Hypothesis 4 will be significant for conservatives. We are agnostic about their significance for liberals.

Hypothesis 6a*: The effects described in Hypothesis 6a (mediating role of PRD) will be significant for liberals but not for conservatives.

Hypothesis 6b*: The effects described in Hypothesis 6b (mediating role of SDO) will be significant for conservatives. We are agnostic about their significance for liberals.

question5a.value:
This study draws on literature examining social class and essentialist beliefs. Past research has shown that high social class is associated with beliefs about the essentialism of social class (Kraus & Keltner, 2013), and high (vs. low) social class individuals are more likely to emphasize trait attributions rather than socio-environmental attributions (Kraus et al., 2012). As such, we predict individuals with higher SSC-Com should have less malleable lay beliefs about (a) intelligence and (b) social class and (c) more essentialist beliefs about social class (Hypothesis 1). These beliefs are chosen because they tap into the vertical, hierarchical nature of social class.  

Personal Relative Deprivation (PRD) is a measure of how unfair and disadvantaged an individual believes they are relative to a group or individual (Smith et al., 2012). As both SSC-Com and PRD have to do with an individual’s rank relative to society, and as individuals with higher subjective social class generally feel less relative deprivation (Callan, Kim, Gheorghiu & Matthews, 2017), we expect that SSC-Com is a negative predictor of PRD (Hypothesis 2). However, at the same time, individuals who experience higher levels of PRD are expected to feel like their current situation (in having less than they believe they deserve) is due to causes they cannot control, leading to a more fixed worldview. We expect PRD to predict less malleable lay beliefs of intelligence and social class and more essentialist beliefs about social class (Hypothesis 3).

Social Dominance Orientation (SDO), a measure of individuals’ endorsement of beliefs of group hierarchy (Ho, Sidanius, Kteily, & Sheehy-Skeffington, 2016), is also likely reflected in how individuals compare themselves with others in their community. We propose that individuals with higher levels of SSC-Com will also have higher levels of SDO (Hypothesis 4). In turn, greater endorsement of group hierarchy should also be reflected in less malleable lay beliefs about intelligence and social class and more essentialist beliefs about social class (Hypothesis 5). We also posit that the effects of SSC-Com on these beliefs are mediated through PRD (Hypothesis 6a) and SDO (Hypothesis 6b), which represent two facets of vertical hierarchy. 

At the same time, there has been growing evidence for political conservatism as motivated cognition. Conservative individuals have various cognitive styles and mechanisms towards resisting change, justifying inequality, accepting current social structures, and endorsing group-based dominance (Jost et al., 2003; Van Hiel & Mervielde, 2002). Endorsement of group-based dominance has been suggested to serve as a way for individuals to justify favourable social ranking and position of power over other groups (Schmitt, Branscombe & Kappen, 2003) and liberals has consistently been shown to endorse less group-based dominance and more egalitarian values than conservatives (Kugler, Jost & Noorbaloochi, 2014; Milojev et al., 2014). As such, liberals may favor more malleable and constructivist explanations overall. Since intelligence and class are desirable features, we expect conservatives to favor more fixed and dispositional explanations for their social ranking, a tendency that should increase with how well they think they are doing relative to others. In other words, we posit that higher SSC-Com will predict less malleable lay beliefs of intelligence and social class and more essentialist beliefs about social class for conservatives, but not for liberals (Hypothesis 1*). 

Other tenets of conservative ideology include resistance to change, acceptance of inequality, and acceptance of social structures. Accordingly, how deprived conservatives feel relative to similar others should be relatively stable regardless of their subjective social rank. We thus predict no significant effect of SSC-Com on PRD for conservatives, whereas for liberals we expect higher SSC-Com to predict lower levels of PRD (Hypothesis 2*). It follows that we predict the mediating effects of PRD to be significant for liberals but not for conservatives (Hypothesis 6a*). 

In addition, greater endorsement of group hierarchy is associated with individuals of high status (Sidanius, Levin & Pratto, 1996), and research suggests conservatives (relative to liberals) are more likely to have favourable self-enhancements (Wojcik et al., 2015) and have greater endorsement of group hierarchy (Van Hiel & Mervielde, 2002). Taken together, these findings suggest that when conservatives perceive their subjective social status to be high, they would also have higher levels of SDO as a way to further enhance their status. We posit that for conservatives, SSC-Com predicts higher levels of SDO (Hypothesis 4*) and SDO mediates the effects of SSC-Com on lay beliefs about (a) intelligence and (b) social class and (c) essentialist beliefs about social class (Hypothesis 6b*). Since liberals have been shown to be lower than conservatives in self-enhancement as well as general endorsement for group hierarchy, we are agnostic about the effect of SSC-Com on SDO and the mediating role of SDO in the effects of SSC-Com on lay beliefs about (a) intelligence and (b) social class and (c) essentialist beliefs about social class for liberals.

question1c.value: For each variable, a composite score will be computed by averaging across items. SSC-Com, PRD, SDO, and political orientation will be standardized. Political orientation will also be transformed into a dichotomous variable such that individuals who identify as “Very liberal”, “Moderately liberal” and “Slightly liberal” will be combined as “Liberal” and individuals who identify as “Very conservative”, “Moderately conservative” and “Slightly conservative” will be combined as “Conservative.” This dichotomous variable will be used to create the conservative and liberal datasets used to test Hypothesis 1*, Hypothesis 2*, Hypothesis 4*, Hypothesis 6a*, and Hypothesis 6b*.

question2c.value: Path analysis, model comparison, and regression.

question3c.value:
The moderator variable political orientation will be multiplied with SSC-Com, PRD, and SDO (all standardized) to create interaction terms to be used in the path analysis: 
Pathway from SSC-Com to PRD, SDO and the dependent variables (lay beliefs about intelligence, lay beliefs about social class, and essentialist beliefs about social class).
Pathway from PRD to the dependent variables (lay beliefs about intelligence, lay beliefs about social class, and essentialist beliefs about social class). 
Pathway from SDO to the dependent variables (lay beliefs about intelligence, lay beliefs about social class, and essentialist beliefs about social class). 
Political orientation x SSC-Com for the pathways from the independent variable (SSC-Com) to the mediators (PRD and SDO). 
In addition, we will create two new datasets by political orientation (conservatives versus liberals), use the same path analysis above minus the interaction terms, and compare the two models to test for the expected differences between conservatives and liberals.

registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question1a:
Hypothesis 1: Higher levels of Subjective Social Class relative to the Community (SSC-Com) will predict lay beliefs about (a) intelligence and (b) social class as less malleable, and (c) more essentialist beliefs about social class. 

Hypothesis 2: Higher levels of SSC-Com will predict lower levels of Personal Relative Deprivation (PRD). 

Hypothesis 3: Higher levels of PRD will predict lay beliefs about (a) intelligence and (b) social class as less malleable, and (c) more essentialist beliefs about social class.   

Hypothesis 4: Higher levels of SSC-Com will predict higher levels of Social Dominance Orientation (SDO). 

Hypothesis 5: Higher levels of SDO will predict lay beliefs about (a) intelligence and (b) social class as less malleable, and (c) more essentialist beliefs about social class.   

Hypothesis 6: The predictive effects of SSC-Com on beliefs (Hypothesis 1) will be mediated by (a) PRD (Hypotheses 2-3) and (b) SDO (Hypotheses 4-5).
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question2a:
Hypothesis 1*: The effects described in Hypothesis 1 will be significant for conservatives but not for liberals. 

Hypothesis 2*: The effects described in Hypothesis 2 will be significant for liberals but not for conservatives.
  
Hypothesis 4*: The effects described in Hypothesis 4 will be significant for conservatives. We are agnostic about their significance for liberals.

Hypothesis 6a*: The effects described in Hypothesis 6a (mediating role of PRD) will be significant for liberals but not for conservatives.

Hypothesis 6b*: The effects described in Hypothesis 6b (mediating role of SDO) will be significant for conservatives. We are agnostic about their significance for liberals.
registration_responses.recommended-hypothesis.question5a:
This study draws on literature examining social class and essentialist beliefs. Past research has shown that high social class is associated with beliefs about the essentialism of social class (Kraus & Keltner, 2013), and high (vs. low) social class individuals are more likely to emphasize trait attributions rather than socio-environmental attributions (Kraus et al., 2012). As such, we predict individuals with higher SSC-Com should have less malleable lay beliefs about (a) intelligence and (b) social class and (c) more essentialist beliefs about social class (Hypothesis 1). These beliefs are chosen because they tap into the vertical, hierarchical nature of social class.  

Personal Relative Deprivation (PRD) is a measure of how unfair and disadvantaged an individual believes they are relative to a group or individual (Smith et al., 2012). As both SSC-Com and PRD have to do with an individual’s rank relative to society, and as individuals with higher subjective social class generally feel less relative deprivation (Callan, Kim, Gheorghiu & Matthews, 2017), we expect that SSC-Com is a negative predictor of PRD (Hypothesis 2). However, at the same time, individuals who experience higher levels of PRD are expected to feel like their current situation (in having less than they believe they deserve) is due to causes they cannot control, leading to a more fixed worldview. We expect PRD to predict less malleable lay beliefs of intelligence and social class and more essentialist beliefs about social class (Hypothesis 3).

Social Dominance Orientation (SDO), a measure of individuals’ endorsement of beliefs of group hierarchy (Ho, Sidanius, Kteily, & Sheehy-Skeffington, 2016), is also likely reflected in how individuals compare themselves with others in their community. We propose that individuals with higher levels of SSC-Com will also have higher levels of SDO (Hypothesis 4). In turn, greater endorsement of group hierarchy should also be reflected in less malleable lay beliefs about intelligence and social class and more essentialist beliefs about social class (Hypothesis 5). We also posit that the effects of SSC-Com on these beliefs are mediated through PRD (Hypothesis 6a) and SDO (Hypothesis 6b), which represent two facets of vertical hierarchy. 

At the same time, there has been growing evidence for political conservatism as motivated cognition. Conservative individuals have various cognitive styles and mechanisms towards resisting change, justifying inequality, accepting current social structures, and endorsing group-based dominance (Jost et al., 2003; Van Hiel & Mervielde, 2002). Endorsement of group-based dominance has been suggested to serve as a way for individuals to justify favourable social ranking and position of power over other groups (Schmitt, Branscombe & Kappen, 2003) and liberals has consistently been shown to endorse less group-based dominance and more egalitarian values than conservatives (Kugler, Jost & Noorbaloochi, 2014; Milojev et al., 2014). As such, liberals may favor more malleable and constructivist explanations overall. Since intelligence and class are desirable features, we expect conservatives to favor more fixed and dispositional explanations for their social ranking, a tendency that should increase with how well they think they are doing relative to others. In other words, we posit that higher SSC-Com will predict less malleable lay beliefs of intelligence and social class and more essentialist beliefs about social class for conservatives, but not for liberals (Hypothesis 1*). 

Other tenets of conservative ideology include resistance to change, acceptance of inequality, and acceptance of social structures. Accordingly, how deprived conservatives feel relative to similar others should be relatively stable regardless of their subjective social rank. We thus predict no significant effect of SSC-Com on PRD for conservatives, whereas for liberals we expect higher SSC-Com to predict lower levels of PRD (Hypothesis 2*). It follows that we predict the mediating effects of PRD to be significant for liberals but not for conservatives (Hypothesis 6a*). 

In addition, greater endorsement of group hierarchy is associated with individuals of high status (Sidanius, Levin & Pratto, 1996), and research suggests conservatives (relative to liberals) are more likely to have favourable self-enhancements (Wojcik et al., 2015) and have greater endorsement of group hierarchy (Van Hiel & Mervielde, 2002). Taken together, these findings suggest that when conservatives perceive their subjective social status to be high, they would also have higher levels of SDO as a way to further enhance their status. We posit that for conservatives, SSC-Com predicts higher levels of SDO (Hypothesis 4*) and SDO mediates the effects of SSC-Com on lay beliefs about (a) intelligence and (b) social class and (c) essentialist beliefs about social class (Hypothesis 6b*). Since liberals have been shown to be lower than conservatives in self-enhancement as well as general endorsement for group hierarchy, we are agnostic about the effect of SSC-Com on SDO and the mediating role of SDO in the effects of SSC-Com on lay beliefs about (a) intelligence and (b) social class and (c) essentialist beliefs about social class for liberals.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2a: It is a correlational study. All variables are between-participants. The primary independent variable is SSC-Com. The mediators are PRD and SDO.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2b: The dependent variables are lay beliefs about intelligence and social class (Dweck, 2000) and essentialist beliefs about social class (Kraus & Keltner, 2013).
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question3b: The primary moderator is political orientation.
registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question7c: For the path analysis, listwise deletion will be used.
registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10: After providing consent, participants will first answer questions about their subjective social class (Adler, Epel, Castellazzo & Ickovics, 2000). Participants will then answer questions about their lay beliefs about intelligence and social class (Dweck, 2000; 6-items each; 1=Strongly disagree, 6=Strongly agree), and the 10-item measure of essentialist beliefs about social class (Kraus and Keltner, 2013; 1=Strongly disagree, 6=Strongly agree). Participants will complete the 16-item measure of social dominance orientation (SDO7; Ho et al., 2015; 1=Strongly oppose, 7=Strongly favor) and the 5-item measure of personal relative deprivation (Callen, 2008; 1=Strongly disagree, 6=Strongly agree). Participants will also complete questions about their self-income, parental income, self-education, parental education, and a 1-item measure of their political orientation (1=Very liberal, 7=Very Conservative). In addition, we will be measuring general demographic variables (e.g., race, gender). Finally, participants will be debriefed and receive a code which they will have to enter into Mturk to receive compensation for their participation in the study.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi: For each variable, a composite score will be computed by averaging across items. SSC-Com, PRD, SDO, and political orientation will be standardized. Political orientation will also be transformed into a dichotomous variable such that individuals who identify as “Very liberal”, “Moderately liberal” and “Slightly liberal” will be combined as “Liberal” and individuals who identify as “Very conservative”, “Moderately conservative” and “Slightly conservative” will be combined as “Conservative.” This dichotomous variable will be used to create the conservative and liberal datasets used to test Hypothesis 1*, Hypothesis 2*, Hypothesis 4*, Hypothesis 6a*, and Hypothesis 6b*.
Path analysis, model comparison, and regression.

The moderator variable political orientation will be multiplied with SSC-Com, PRD, and SDO (all standardized) to create interaction terms to be used in the path analysis: 
Pathway from SSC-Com to PRD, SDO and the dependent variables (lay beliefs about intelligence, lay beliefs about social class, and essentialist beliefs about social class).
Pathway from PRD to the dependent variables (lay beliefs about intelligence, lay beliefs about social class, and essentialist beliefs about social class). 
Pathway from SDO to the dependent variables (lay beliefs about intelligence, lay beliefs about social class, and essentialist beliefs about social class). 
Political orientation x SSC-Com for the pathways from the independent variable (SSC-Com) to the mediators (PRD and SDO). 
In addition, we will create two new datasets by political orientation (conservatives versus liberals), use the same path analysis above minus the interaction terms, and compare the two models to test for the expected differences between conservatives and liberals.
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: Based on the power analysis, the largest number of participants needed to detect the smallest hypothesized effect is 1350 participants. Expecting about 10% dropout or unusable data, we will be collecting data from 1500 participants.
Participants will be collected via the online platform Amazon Mechanical Turk.

The sample size was based on a power analysis using the relevant path estimates from an earlier exploratory study. The lavaan package (Rosseel, 2012) was used to model the pathways in the path analysis. The simsem package (Jorgensen, Pornprasertmanit, Miller & Schoemann, 2018) was used to run simulation models to find the sample size needed for .80 power at .05 alpha (see attached file).
We will stop collecting data once we reach our target sample size.
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q:
1. Participants who do not answer the attention checks correctly will be excluded from analysis.   
2. Participants will see each variable of interest (SSC-Com, SDO, PRD, Lay Beliefs about Intelligence, Lay Beliefs about Social Class, Essentialist Beliefs of Social Class, and Political Orientation) on a separate page. For these variables, we will have a timer on each page. This timer will be hidden to the participants and only available to the researchers for analysis purposes. Participants who complete the page in less time than the number of items on the page multiplied by 1.5 seconds will be excluded from analysis. 
3. Participants who have the same IP address will be excluded from analysis. 
4. Participants who are not located in the United States will be excluded from analysis.

question10b.value: National Longitudinal Survey of Children and Youth, 1998-1999 [Canada]: Cycle 3, Primary File is used in this study. The survey data was collected by Human Resources Development Canada (HRDC)and Statistics Canada. Randomly selected samples are representative of Canadian children across Canada (excluding children living in the Yukon and Northwest Territories). Monitor and collect data every two years from birth to age 11 into adulthood.

question4b.value: Follow a representative sample of Canadian children 0-13 years of age who are living in Canada.

question5b.value: Data will be collected through a survey answered by the parent, child, and teacher, as well as direct measures from children.

question6b.value: The target sample size is 150 in total, and 75 for each group

question7b.value: It is a longitudinal survey tracing Canadian children to their that terminates after the participant reaches the age of 25.

question8b.value:
1. Exclude children living in the Yukon and Northwest Territories.
2. Exclude children who did not provide a PPVT-R score. 
3. Exclude missing data or data that we are not able to trace.
4. Excluding univariate outliers based on Z-scores (scores in the too extreme ends).

question10c.value:
1. Assume normally distributed data.

2. Assume no outliers

question1a.value: 1. Children who have relatives trained in early childhood education have a better receptive vocabulary in English than children who do not have relatives trained in early childhood education.

question3a.value: the study not in an experimental setting, it is based on questionnaires with no manipulated variables.

question5a.value: Adults who trained in early childhood education will weigh early childhood education as more important compared to adults who did not receive training in early childhood education. Therefore people trained in early childhood education will focus more on the early education of their children or young relatives. Thus, we focus on testing the perceptive vocabulary in English using PPVT-R to find the relationship between children's vocabulary and their parent(s) education in early childhood education.

question1c.value:

2. Standard PPVT score of the child

2. Dependent variable: Standard PPVT score of the child
